column2: 【n.】 1) [U] determination to be successful, rich, powerful, etc. 抱负；雄心；野心
column3: She was intelligent but suffered from a lack of ambition.

column2: 【n.】 2) [C] a strong desire to achieve sth. 追求；夙愿；理想
column3: Earlier this year, he achieved his ambition of competing in the Olympic Games.

column2: 【a.】 determined to be successful, rich, powerful, etc. 有抱负的；有雄心的；野心勃勃的
column3: She's extremely ambitious and intends to be running her own company by the time she's 30.

column2: 【ad.】 (also 'some day') at an unknown time in the future, esp. a long time in the future 将来会有一天；有朝一日
column3: He hopes, someday, to have his own business.

column2: 【ad.】 in a way that shows no emotion when you are talking about sth. exciting, frightening, etc. 就事论事地；不带感情地；实事求是地
column3: To my surprise, he spoke about his divorce matter-of-factly.

column2: 【n.】 [U] the scientific study of living things 生物学
column3: Students might pursue a degree in biology as a path to medical school or a variety of professions.

column2: 【vt.】 find a satisfactory way of dealing with a problem or difficulty 解决（问题、困难）
column3: There weren't enough beds, but the matter was resolved by George sleeping on the sofa.

column2: 【n.】 [U] books and stories about imaginary people and events 小说
column3: The book is a work of fiction and not intended as a historical account.

column2: 【n.】 [C] (AmE) a student in the first year of high school or university （高中或大学的）一年级学生
column3: It is necessary for freshmen to get to know their new studying environment in university as soon as possible.

column2: 【v.】 behave as if sth. is true when in fact you know it is not, in order to deceive people or for fun 假装；装作
column3: She pretended that she was not at home when we rang the bell.

column2: 【a.】 1) (~ for sth.; ~ to do sth.) needing or wanting sth. very much 非常需要···的；极其需要···的
column3: The healthcare industry is desperate for solutions to its business models.

column2: 【a.】 2) willing to do anything to change a very bad situation, and not caring about danger （为了改变糟糕境遇而）不惜冒险的，拼命的，绝望的
column3: I had no money left and was desperate.

column2: 【n.】 [C] (infml.) a friend 朋友；伙伴
column3: Bob and I have been great buddies for years.

column2: 【a.】 amusing and interesting 使人愉快的；有趣的
column3: His books aren't particularly well-written, but they're always entertaining.

column2: 【a.】 showing or saying that you are sorry that sth. has happened, esp. because you feel guilty or embarrassed about it 道歉的；谢罪的；愧疚的
column3: She was apologetic about my injury.

column2: 【vt.】 succeed in achieving sth. after trying for a long time （通过长时间努力而）得到，获得，赢得
column3: More and more women are attaining positions of power.

column2: 【a.】 possible to achieve, reach, or get 可以达到的；可以获得的
column3: We must make sure that we do not set ourselves goals that are not attainable.

column2: 【n.】 [U] the quality of trying to do sth. even when it is difficult 决心；坚韧；毅力
column3: He shows great determination to learn English.

column2: 【a.】 accepting things as they are in fact and not making decisions based on unlikely hopes for the future 现实的；实际的；实事求是的
column3: Let's be realistic about this 一 I just can't afford to pay that much money.

column2: 【n.】 [C, U] a thick tropical forest with many large plants growing very close together （热带）丛林
column3: We had to cut our way through dense jungle.

column2: 【a.】 certain to happen or to do sth. because a mysterious force is controlling events 命运决定的；命中注定的
column3: She says she was fated to become a writer.

column2: 【a.】 1) eager to go to new places and do exciting or dangerous things 喜欢冒险的；有冒险精神的
column3: I took an adventurous ski trip in Austria last year.

column2: 【a.】 2) not afraid of taking risks or trying new things 大胆创新的
column3: Warren is a very adventurous cook, always trying to make new dishes.

column2: 【a.】 sth. that is exotic seems unusual and interesting because it is related to a foreign country 异国风情的；外国情调的
column3: She likes traveling to all kinds of exotic locations.

column2: [n.] 1) [C] (~ of) a group of similar things 一系列
column3: We've had a string of complaints about the program.

column2: [n.] 2) [C, U]（由几股合成的）线，细绳，带子
column3: Her key hung on a string around her neck.

column2: [vt.]3) (strung, strung) put things together onto a thread, chain, etc. 用（线、 链等）穿起来
column3: She had strung the shells on a silver chain.

column2: 【n.】 [C, U] a state of disagreement or argument between people, groups, countries, etc. （意见等的）抵触，冲突，矛盾
column3: She found herself in conflict with her parents over her future career.

column2: 【ad.】 in a way that involves all your feelings, interest, etc. 全心全意地；全力以赴地
column3: I agree whole-heartedly with the mayor on this issue.

column2: 【ad.】 if one person does sth. single-mindedly, they have one clear aim and work very hard to achieve it 一心一意地；专心致志地
column3: His ability to concentrate single-mindedly on the most important thing leads to his success.

column2: 【a.】 always wanting more food, money, power, possessions, etc. than you need 贪婪的；贪心的； 贪吃的；贪喝的
column3: He looked at the gold with greedy eyes.

column2: 【a.】 a chaotic situation is one in which everything is happening in a confused way 混乱的； 毫无秩序的
column3: The traffic in the city is chaotic in the rush hour.

column2: 【a.】 1) if sb. /sth. is overdue, they should have arrived before now 迟到的；延误的
column3: If you're overdue for a vacation, you can prepare for an adventure instead of cancelling it.

column2: 【a.】 2) not done, paid, returned, etc. by the time expected 过期未完成的；过期未付的；过期未还的
column3: These books are overdue and you should pay a fine.

column2: 【a.】 sb., esp. a child or young person, who is mature behaves in a sensible and reasonable way, as you would expect an adult to behave （尤指小孩或年轻人举止）成熟的，理智的，明白事理的
column3: We're mature enough to disagree on this issue but still respect each other.

column2: 【vt.】 give sb. a particular job or make them responsible for a particular person or thing 分配，分派，指派（任务）
column3: I've been assigned the task of looking after the new students.

column2: 【n.】 [C] a doctor who deals with children and their illnesses 儿科医生
column3: He dreams of becoming a doctor, specifically a pediatrician.

column2: 【n.】 [C] a popular product, esp. a book, that many people buy 畅销产品；畅销书
column3: His new book went straight to No. 1 on the best-seller list.

column2: 【ad.】 (often used in negative sentences or questions) any longer 再也（不）；（不）再
column3: You're describing a world that just doesn't exist anymore.

column2: 【vi.】 (strove, striven) (~ to do sth.; ~ for / after sth.)  make a great effort to achieve sth. 努力；奋斗
column3: We encourage all members to strive for the highest standards.

column2: 【a.】 (only before noun) extremely popular 畅销的
column3: It's almost every author's dream to become a best-selling author.

column2: 【n.】 [C] a meeting held by a person or group at which they answer questions from people who write or present news reports 记者招待会；新闻发布会
column3: The football coach held a press conference to announce his retirement.

column2: 【a.】 attractive or interesting 有吸引力的；有趣的
column3: The city offers an appealing combination of sporting and cultural events.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 舌；舌头
【n.】 [C, U] a feeling of sadness that makes you think there is no hope for the future 忧伤；沮丧；消沉
column3: She suffered from severe depression after losing her job.

column2: 【n.】 [U] 1) when sb. feels alone and unable to meet or speak to other people 孤独；孤单
column3: After all the visitors had left, she experienced a feeling of complete isolation.

column2: 【n.】 [U] 2) when one group, person, or thing is separate from others 隔绝；孤立；分离
column3: Because of its geographical isolation, the area developed its own unique culture.

column2: 【n.】 [C] sb. who is paid to work for sb. else 受雇者；雇员
column3: e.g.  Alibaba Group has more than 100,000 global employees.

column2: 【n.】 [C] sb. who studies and develops ideas about the nature and meaning of existence, truth, good and evil, etc. 哲学家
column3: Socrates and Plato are two famous Greek philosophers whose ideas are still influential today.

column2: 【v.】 if a story, plan, etc. unfolds, it becomes clearer as you hear or learn more about it （使）（故事、计划等）展开；逐渐呈现；展示
column3: The scandal is still unfolding, but there may be a solution soon.

column2: 【n.】 [C] sb.'s general attitude, and the way in which they think about things and make decisions 思维模式
column3: It's quite difficult to change the mindset of the public and the press.

column2: 【v.】 become smaller in size, importance, or value, or make sth. do this （使）降低；（使）减少
column3: The new project will lessen the effects of car pollution.

column2: 【a.】 (only before noun) relating to your feelings or how you control them 情绪（上）的；情感（上）的
column3: Mothers are often the ones who provide emotional support for the family.

column2: 【vt.】 1) (fml.) notice, see, or recognize sth. 察觉；注意到；发觉
column3: That morning, he perceived a change in his wife's mood.

column2: 【vt.】 2) (written) understand or think of sb. / sth. in a particular way （以某种方式）看待，理解
column3: Even as a young woman she had been perceived as a future chief executive.

column2: 【a.】 extremely brave or determined, and admired by many people 英雄的；英勇的
column3: These doctors performed heroic work in difficult conditions.

column2: 【a.】 always behaving in the same way or having the same attitudes, standards, etc. （行为、态度、标准等）一贯的，一致的
column3: He has been the team's most consistent player.

column2: 【a.】 able to continue for a long time 可持续的
column3: That sort of extreme diet is not sustainable over a long period.

column2: 【n.】 [U] when you are healthy and strong enough to do hard work or play sports 健壮；健康
column3: They're doing some regular exercise to improve their fitness.

column2: 【n.】 [U] the ability to use your imagination to produce new ideas, make things, etc. 独创性；创造性；创造力
column3: We should have an education system that lets children use their creativity.

column2: 【n.】 [U] a long race of about 42 kilometers or 26 miles 马拉松赛跑
column3: She ran her first marathon in just under three hours.

column2: 【ad.】 1) used to emphasize that sth., esp. a large number, is actually true 的确；确实
column3: The Olympic Games were watched by literally billions of people around the world.

column2: 【ad.】 2) according to the most basic or original meaning of a word or expression 按照原意；根据字面意思
column3: I said I felt like quitting, but I didn't mean it literally.

column2: 【vt.】 try to do or use too much of sth., causing problems, illness, or damage 把···做得过分；把···使用过头
column3: e.g .  Be careful not to overextend yourself. You've been very ill.

column2: 【vt.】 (be obsessed with  sth. obsesses you, you think or worry about them all the time and you cannot think about anything else 一 used to show disapproval 使痴迷；使迷恋；使心神不宁（含贬义）
column3: A lot of young girls are obsessed by their weight.

column2: 【a.】 (only before noun) the maximum amount, quantity, speed, etc. is the largest that is possible or is allowed 最大量的；最大限度的；最大值的
column3: To get the maximum benefit, do the exercises slowly.

column2: 【n.】 [C] a period of physical exercise, esp. as training for a sport 体育锻炼；训练
column3: She does a 20-minute workout every morning.

column2: 【prep.】 used to contrast sb. / sth. with another person or thing 与···不同
column3: Unlike most people in the office, I don't come to work by car.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 1) a situation that seems strange because it involves two ideas or qualities that are very different 自相矛盾（的情况）
column3: It is a paradox that in such a rich country there can be so much poverty.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 2) a statement that seems impossible because it contains two opposing ideas that are both true 悖论；似非而是的说法
column3: The paradox is that fishermen would catch more fish if they fished less.

column2: vi. (~ well  差等
column3: The company has been performing poorly over the past year.

column2: v.  do sth. to entertain people, for example by acting a play or playing a piece of music 表演；演出
column3: I'd like to hear the music performed live.

column2: 【v.】 1) use a lot of time and effort trying to get sth. such as work or money 努力赢得；设法获得
column3: Top graduates from the university are chased by major companies.

column2: 【v.】 2) quickly follow sb. / sth. in order to catch them 追逐；追赶；追捕
column3: The dogs saw him running and chased him.

column2: 【a.】 1) sb. who is grounded understands their own character and knows what is really important 对自己有清醒认识的
column3: Mary says that she knows what she really wants because her family always keeps her grounded.

column2: 【a.】 2）reasonable and in control of your emotions, even when this is difficult 理性的；有理智的；克制的
column3: Charles can always keep himself grounded, even when he runs into difficulty.

column2: 【a.】 producing or achieving a lot 多产的；丰饶的；富有成效的
column3: We had a very productive meeting 一 I felt we sorted out a lot of problems.

column2: 【n.】 [sing.] the set of ideas and moral attitudes that are typical of a particular group （某团体的）精神特质，道德意识
column3: It is a community in which people lived according to an ethos of sharing and caring.

column2: (infml.) if sth. is yours for the asking, you can have it if you want it 某人只要提出要求（就可以得到）
column3: A good deal of extra support is hers for the asking.

column2: have great success 大获成功
column3: I wasn't expecting it to work, but I hit it big when I tried the new approach.

column2: (spoken) used when giving your personal opinion or admitting sth. 老实说；实话对你讲
column3: To tell the truth, I don't really like her.

column2: not take sb. / sth. with you when you leave a place 忘记带走；留下
column3: He departed for the United States, leaving the children behind with his mother.

column2: relax and make no effort to get involved in sth. or influence what happens 不采取行动；袖手旁观
column3: Don't just sit back and wait for new business to come to you.

column2: used for saying that there is more than one reason for sth. 由于这样或那样的原因
column3: His travel articles are always, for one reason or another, fascinating.

column2: (infml.) take an opportunity, accept an invitation, etc. immediately 抓住（机会）；立即接受（邀请等）
column3: This is our chance to grab at this new market.

column2: accept an unpleasant or sad situation and no longer feel upset or angry about it 与某事妥协，对某事让步；接受（令人不快或悲伤的现实）
column3: It's hard for the couple to come to terms with the fact that they will never have children.

column2: prevent sb.  某事发展
column3: Do you think that mixed-ability teaching holds the brighter children back?

column2: (infml.) if a name or phrase rolls or trips off your tongue, it is easy or pleasant to say （某个名字或短语）顺口
column3: Their names roll off the tongue very easily.

column2: be in a state of physical or mental exhaustion caused by overwork or stress 感到精疲力竭
column3: He was burned out by the time he was 21 and retired from the sport.

column2: the present time 现时
column3: To be able to live fully in the here and now, one must first learn how to honor the past.

column2: fail to win or achieve sth. 未能赢取；未能获得
column3: We're so close to getting the job done, but we keep coming up short.

column2: increase by small amounts until there is a large total 积累；积少成多
column3: When you're feeding a family of six the bills soon add up.

column2: combine things in order to make sth. that is complete, good, useful, etc. 把···拼在一起
column3: They string together image after image until the documentary is completed.

column2: (fml.) before 在···以前
column3: All the arrangements should be completed prior to your departure.

column2: if you are at peace, you do not feel angry, unhappy, etc. 心平气和的
column3: For the first time in months, she felt calm and at peace with the world.

column2: I didn't feel sleepy at all 一 just the opposite, in fact.
be the opposite of 违背某事；与某事背道而驰
column3: The governor's newest policy seems to be running counter to everything he promised during his election campaign.
